coredata.dc:title: Inherently flame-retardant solid polymer electrolyte for safety-enhanced lithium metal battery
coredata.dc:creator: Li, Hongping
Yang, Jun
Chen, Suli
Xu, Zhixin
Wang, Jiulin
Nuli, Yanna
Guo, Yongsheng
Liang, Chengdu
coredata.dc:description: The solid polymer electrolyte (SPE) has been regarded as a promising candidate for the next-generation rechargeable Li metal battery with high-energy density. However, the current SPEs are still challenged by insufficient security owing to their flammability. Here, we reported a novel inherently flame-retardant SPE (IFR-SPE), which was fabricated via the one-step in situ crosslinking of two novel synthetic P-containing monomers with porous polyimide film as a supporting host. Compared with liquid and conventional solid polyethylene oxide electrolytes, the unique IFR-SPE exhibits outstanding flame-retardant ability. Furthermore, it demonstrates a high Li-ion conductivity (0.28 mS cm−1 at 25 °C), a stable electrochemical window up to 4.12 V, and effective Li dendrite suppression via a LiF/Li3PO4-rich solid electrolyte interphase formed on the Li anode. Consequently, the Li/IFR-SPE/LiFePO4 cell shows acceptable electrochemical performances. We believe that this work offers a novel and effective strategy for establishing a promising Li metal battery system with high safety.
coredata.dcterms:subject: Flame-retardation
Solid polymer electrolyte
Lithium metal battery
Safety issue

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: Synthetic routes of (a) OPTTA and (b) BEPA.
(a) Preparation route of 3D IFR-SPE framework. (b) Schematic diagram for the formation of integrated cell.
SEM photographs of (a) PI film, (b) cross-section and (c) surface of IFR-SPE. (d) Distribution of carbon, nitrogen, oxygen, fluorine, phosphorus, and sulfur on the surface of IFR-SPE.

(a) FTIR spectra of BEPA, OPTTA, and IFR-SPE. (b) XRD patterns of solid PEO electrolyte and IFR-SPE. (c) Digital Photographs of the thermal shrinkage of PP, PI, PEO, and IFR-SPE before and after exposure to 150 °C for 30 min. (d) TGA curve of IFR-SPE.
Flame tests of polymer films absorbed with carbonate solvents: (a) PP, (b) PEO/LiFSI, and (c) IFR-SPE. (d) Mechanism of the the flame retardant effects of IFR-SPE.

(a) Temperature-dependent ionic conductivities of SS/IFR-SPE/SS blocking cells at different LiFSI concentrations. (b) EIS of Li/IFR-SPE/Li symmetrical cell at different aging times. (c) LSV of the polymer electrolyte at a scan rate of 1 mV S−1 by using stainless steel as working electrode and Li as the counter and reference electrode. The surface morphologies of Li metal electrodes for Li/Li symmetric cell with (d) IFR-SPE and (e) liquid electrolyte after 100 cycles at current density of 0.2 mA cm−2 and areal capacity of 0.2 mAh cm−2. (f) Li plating/stripping voltage profiles of Li/Li symmetric cell with IFR-SPE at 0.5 mA cm−2 and 0.5 mAh cm−2. XPS spectra of the Li metal anode surface after 100 cycles at 0.2 mA cm−2 and 0.2 mAh cm−2 for (g) P 2p and (h) F 1 s.
(a) Charge/discharge cycle performance of Li/IFR-SPE/LiFePO4 cell at 0.2C and ambient temperature. (b) Rate performance of Li/IFR-SPE/LiFePO4 cell in the voltage range of 2.5–4.0 V.

head.ce:title: Inherently flame-retardant solid polymer electrolyte for safety-enhanced lithium metal battery

ce:affiliation.ce:label: a
ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Shanghai Electrochemical Energy Devices Research Center, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai 200240, PR China

School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering

ce:affiliation.ce:source-text: Research Institute, Ningde Contemporary Amperex Technology Co., Limited, Fujian 352100, PR China

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: The solid polymer electrolyte (SPE) has been regarded as a promising candidate for the next-generation rechargeable Li metal battery with high-energy density. However, the current SPEs are still challenged by insufficient security owing to their flammability. Here, we reported a novel inherently flame-retardant SPE (IFR-SPE), which was fabricated via the one-step in situ crosslinking of two novel synthetic P-containing monomers with porous polyimide film as a supporting host. Compared with liquid and conventional solid polyethylene oxide electrolytes, the unique IFR-SPE exhibits outstanding flame-retardant ability. Furthermore, it demonstrates a high Li-ion conductivity (0.28 mS cm−1 at 25 °C), a stable electrochemical window up to 4.12 V, and effective Li dendrite suppression via a LiF/Li3PO4-rich solid electrolyte interphase formed on the Li anode. Consequently, the Li/IFR-SPE/LiFePO4 cell shows acceptable electrochemical performances. We believe that this work offers a novel and effective strategy for establishing a promising Li metal battery system with high safety.

ce:section.ce:para: The Li metal is well regarded as “Holy Grail” anode material for next generation rechargeable battery because it has the highest theoretical capacity (3860 mA h g−1, 10 times that of commercial graphite anode) and lowest electrochemical potential (−3.04 V versus SHE) among all possible anode materials [1–4]. However, the development of Li metal batteries (LMBs) is hindered by severe safety concerns. (1) The organic liquid electrolyte is volatile, flammable, and leaks easily [5,6]. (2) The continuous growth of Li dendrites during repeated plating/stripping processes can pierce the separator, cause battery short circuit, and further arouse fire and explosion [7,8]. Numerous efforts have been devoted to address the safety issues of liquid battery, such as adding electrolyte additives [9,10] adopting high-salt concentration electrolytes [11,12] coating inorganic particles on separators [13] using fire-retardant liquid electrolytes [14] creating an alloy surface on the Li metal [15] or a solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) [16] and developing solid electrolytes [17,18].

Among these strategies, solid polymer electrolytes (SPEs) not only overcome the persistent defects of liquid electrolytes, such as electrolyte leakage, toxicity and explosion, but also offer the possibilities for developing integrated and flexible batteries [6 19,20]. However, the practical application of SPEs is mainly limited by two defects. Firstly, SPEs exhibit low ionic conductivity at room temperature. The Li+ movement is hindered by slow segmental relaxation and part of the polymer crystallinity [21]. Secondly, the SPE that is prepared by casting method often has incomplete interface contact with electrodes.

To address the first issue, extensive efforts, such as blending of polymers [22] copolymerization [23] crosslinking [24,25] and adding inorganic fillers [26,27] or plasticizers, have been adopted to address this problem. Y. Cui et al. developed a composite polymer electrolyte on the basis of the chemical crosslinking of polyethylene oxide (PEO) and monodispersed ultrafine SiO2, which suppressed the polymer crystallinity and led to a high Li-ion conductivity (4.4 × 10−5 S cm−1 at 30 °C) [28]. J. Ma et al. prepared a polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF)–polyvinyl acetate-based SPE selectively wetted by tetramethylene sulfone for high-voltage Li/LiCoO2 battery, which demonstrated high Li-ion conductivity and excellent cycle and rate capability [29].

To address the second issue, the in-situ polymerization in the assembled cells for polymer electrolyte formation has recently attracted attention due to the advantages of intimate electrolyte/electrode interface contact and simple assembly (similar to the assembly of liquid electrolyte cell) advantages [30]. G.L Cui et al. proposed a poly(vinylene carbonate) (PVCA)-based polymer electrolyte via a facile in-situ polymerization method, which possessed good interfacial contact and compatibility with electrodes. The initial interface impedance between PVCA-GPE and lithium metal is 190 Ω for the in-situ polymerization, while that is 1400 Ω for ex-situ polymerization [31].

Although great progress has been made, SPE is still suffering from high flammability even under the addition of 30 wt% inorganic fillers [32]. Triethyl phosphate and trimethyl phosphate are flame-retardant solvents that provide fire-extinguishing function when catching fires [5,33,34]. Specifically, the small radical species containing P ([P]·) is generated by an external heat source and further scavenge the main active agent (H· radicals) of combustion chain branching reactions [35]. The chemical reaction is as follows: [P]· + H· = [P]H. In fact, P-containing polymer materials with flame-retardant ability on the basis of the similar mechanism have been added in cotton, plastic, and rubber for their safe use in our daily life [36–38]. Besides, polyimide (PI) is also a good flame-retardant material, which does not catch fire.

Inspired by the above findings, we realize that the SPEs with flame-retardant functionality may have potential to fundamentally solve the safety issues of LMBs. Here, we design and prepare an IFR-SPE via one-step in situ polymerization of two novel synthetic monomers with P by using porous PI film as a supporting framework to settle the flammability issue of SPEs. First, two P-containing monomers, 2-((bis(2-(2-(2-methoxyethoxy) ethoxy) ethoxy) phosphoryl) oxy) ethyl acrylate (BEPA) and ((oxo-phosphanetriyl) tris(oxy)) tris(ethane-2,1-diyl) triacrylate (OPTTA) were synthesized. Then, the IFR-SPE was prepared via the in-situ crosslinking of these two synthetic P-containing monomers with porous PI film as a supporting host. The obtained IFR-SPE possesses not only the outstanding flame-retardant ability, but also the sufficient flexibility for abuse like twisting, folding, and unfolding. Furthermore, the IFR-SPE shows high ionic conductivity of 0.28 mS cm−1 at 25 °C and an acceptable electrochemical stability window up to 4.12 V. It is compatible with Li metal electrode and could be used in Li/LiFePO4 cell with enhanced safety.

Phosphorus oxychloride, triethylene glycol monomethyl ether, hydroxyethyl acrylate, and 4-dimethylaminopyridine (DMAP) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. Dichloromethane (DCM), anhydrous MgSO4, triethylamine, and N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (Adamas) were obtained from Shanghai Tansoole platform. AIBN (99%) was obtained from Aladdin Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd. and recrystallized with methanol. PVDF and C black were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. The PI film (thickness: 45 μm) was purchased from Jiangxi Advanced Nanofiber S&T Co., Ltd. The LiFePO4 powder and LiFSI (battery grade) were supplied by Shenzhen Dynanonic Co. and Shenzhen Xinzhoubang Technology Co., Ltd., respectively.

Phosphoryl chloride (15.3 g, 0.1 mol, 1.0 equiv.) was added into 50 mL DCM. The solution was then cooled to 0 °C by an ice bath and magnetically stirred under Ar. Subsequently, a mixed solution of triethylene glycol monomethyl ether (32.84 g, 0.2 mol, 2.0 equiv.), triethylamine (32 g, 0.315 mol, 3.15 equiv.), and DMAP (1.2 g, 0.1 equiv.) in 30 mL DCM was added dropwise to the above solution over the course of 2 h. Then, hydroxyethyl acrylate (11.6 g, 0.1 mol, 1.0 equiv.) in 20 mL DCM was added, and the mixture was stirred for an additional 24 h at room temperature. Triethylamine hydrochloride salt was removed via filtration and the solution was washed with deionized water (3 × 60 mL). The organic layer was purified by stirring over activated C. The solution was further purified with a neutral Al2O3 column and a silica gel column chromatography, and then was dried over anhydrous MgSO4. DCM solvent was removed by rotary evaporation to obtain the final product. The obtained BEPA was added by 4A molecular sieve and stored in the refrigerator

Phosphoryl chloride (15.3 g, 0.1 mol, 1.0 equiv.) was added into 50 mL DCM. The solution was then cooled to 0 °C by an ice bath and magnetically stirred under Ar. Subsequently, a mixed solution of hydroxyethyl acrylate (34.8 g, 0.3 mol, 3.0 equiv.) and triethylamine (32 g, 0.315 mol, 3.15 equiv.) in 50 mL DCM was added dropwise over the course of 2 h to the above solution. Then, the mixture was stirred for additional 24 h at room temperature. Triethylamine hydrochloride salt was removed via filtration and the solution was washed with deionized water (3 × 60 mL). The organic layer was purified by stirring over activated C and the obtained solution was further purified with a neutral Al2O3 column and a silica gel column chromatography. Then, the solution was dried over anhydrous MgSO4. DCM was removed by rotary evaporation to obtain the final product. OPTTA was added by 4A molecular sieve and stored in the refrigerator.

The LiFePO4 electrode was prepared by mixing 80 wt% LiFePO4, 10 wt% C black, and 10 wt% PVDF binder dissolved in NMP. The resulting slurry was pasted onto C-coated Al foil and dried at 70 °C for 1 h in an air-circulating oven and further dried at 100 °C under high vacuum for 6 h. The mass loading of the LiFePO4 active material on the electrodes was 2.0–2.5 mg cm−2.

LiFSI (0.80 g) was added into the solution of BEPA (1.30 g) and OTPPA (0.06 g). Then, 0.90 g FEC (29 wt% of solution) and 0.014 g AIBN (1 wt% of monomer, 0.5 wt% of PPS) were added to the above solution to obtain transparent homogeneous precursor electrolyte under stirring at 25 °C for 1 h. Lastly, the precursor electrolyte solution was injected into 2032-type coin cells with Li metal anode, LiFePO4 cathode, and porous PI film in an Ar-filled glove box (MB-10 compact, MBRAUN) containing less than 0.5 ppm H2O and O2. The porous PI film was used as a supporting framework and separator for preventing cell short-circuit before in-situ polymerization. After assembly, the cells stayed for 2 h to completely wet the electrolyte/electrode interface and the PI membrane. Finally, they were heated and kept at 70 °C for 24 h for the polymerization and the solidification of the precursor solution. Here, the thicknesses of lithium foil, polymer electrolyte, and cathode foil is 300 μm, 45 μm and 49 μm, respectively.

The morphologies of the PI membrane and the polymer electrolyte were investigated using the FEI Nova SEM 230 ultra-high resolution FESEM (USA). Energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) was used to observe the elemental distribution of the polymer electrolyte. The chemical structure of samples was recorded on an FTIR spectrometer (Bruker VECTOR22) in the frequency range of 400–4000 cm−1 with a resolution of 4 cm−1 and 32 scans. TGA (STA449F3) was adopted to examine the thermal stability of IFR-SPE under Ar atmosphere in the temperature range from room temperature to 800 °C at a heating/cooling rate of 10 °C min−1. The 1H, 13C, and 31P NMR spectra of BEPA and ETPPA were recorded on the Bruker AVANCE III HD 500 MHz by using tetramethylsilane as an internal reference and CDCl3 as a solvent at room temperature.

The ionic conductivities (σ) of the polymer electrolyte between two stainless steel (SS) disks were measured by electrochemical AC impedance spectroscopy (EIS) technique using CHI760e electrochemical workstation from the high frequency 1 MHz to low value of 1 Hz. The conductivities were calculated using the following equation:
σ =
l
R × S

where σ presents the ionic conductivity, R, S and l correspond to bulk impedance of the electrolyte film, the effective contact area (1.91 cm2) between the electrode and electrolyte, and the film thickness, respectively.

The electrochemical anodic stability of polymer electrolyte was evaluated by linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) with SS/polymer electrolyte/Li coin cell at a scan rate of 0.1 mV s−1 from open circuit voltage to 6 V vs. Li+/Li, where stainless steel (SS) was working electrode and Li was counter/reference electrodes.

The cycling performances of assembled cells were evaluated at various charge/discharge rates at room temperature on a LAND battery test system (Wuhan Kingnuo Electronics Co., Ltd., China). The cut-off voltage was 4.0 V for charging and 2.5 V for discharging. Meanwhile, all the test cells would be activated by a small current rate of 0.1C in the initial 2 cycles.

The synthetic pathways of OPTTA and BEPA are shown as Fig. 1 a and 1b, respectively. 1H, 13C, 31P nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy and mass spectrum analysis confirmed the successful synthesis of two monomers OPTTA and BEPA (Supporting Information, Fig. S1–S4). The characteristic resonance peaks of both triethylene glycol monomethyl ether (–CH2–CH2–O– repeating units, 3.56–3.77 ppm; –OCH3, 3.40 ppm) and hydroxyethyl acrylate (–CH = CH2, 5.85–6.50 ppm) can be observed in the 1H NMR spectrum from the BEPA monomer (Fig. S1). The 13C NMR spectrum in Fig. S2 (a) also shows that the BEPA has evident peaks of CH2 = CH– (131.5 and 128.0 ppm) and –CH2–CH2–O– repeating units (70.6 ppm). Furthermore, the 31P NMR spectrum was used to characterize the phosphate ester structure of BEPA. As shown in Fig. S3 (a), the characteristic resonance peak of phosphorus was at − 1.05 ppm. The mass spectrum of BEPA in Fig. S4 (a) exhibits the [M + H] peak at 489.2 and the [M + Na] peak at 511.2. All above tests confirm the formation of BEPA monomer.

After the substitution reaction of hydroxyethyl acrylate and POCl3, the 1H NMR spectrum of the crosslinker OPTTA in Fig. S1 (d) presents a characteristic peak (–CH2 = CH–, 5.85–6.50 ppm) and an increased chemical shift (–PO–CH2–CH2, 4.30 and 4.38 ppm) from –CH2–CH2–COO– (3.88 and 4.32 ppm). As shown in Fig. S2 (b), typical peaks of CH2 = CH– (131.5 and 128.0 ppm) and –O–CH2–CH2–O– (65.6 and 62.9 ppm) are observable in the 13C NMR spectrum of OPTTA. Besides, the 31P NMR spectrum in Fig. S3 (b) presents a typical peak at –1.35 ppm. The mass spectrum of OPTTA in Fig. S4 (b) displays the [M + H] peak at 393.1 and the [M + Na] peak at 415.1. All the above analysis results indicate that the crosslinker OPTTA has been successfully synthesized.

The preparation route of three-dimensional (3D) crosslinked IFR-SPE framework and the schematic diagram for the formation of an integrated cell are shown in Fig. 2 a and 2b, respectively. In detail, a polymeric precursor solution (PPS) was prepared by mixing BEPA, OPTTA, Li bis(fluorosulfonyl)imide (LiFSI), 29 wt% fluoroethylene carbonate (FEC, acting as plasticizer and SEI-forming additive for the Li anode), and azodiisobutyronitrile (AIBN, 1 wt% of monomers) as thermal radical initiator. After PPS inpouring, cell assembly, and heating at 70 °C for 24 h, BEPA and OPTTA were crosslinked under the radical polymerization. Finally, the in situ polymerized and integrated cell was obtained.

The morphology and structure of IFR-SPE have been examined by various analysis technologies. Similar to other porous membrane materials [39], SEM image in Fig. 3 a shows that the PI membrane is composed of random nanofibers with large-sized pores, which can be used as a supporting framework for the polymer electrolyte. As shown in Fig. S5, porous PI membrane possesses good wettability to PPS, leading to the effective adsorption and the uniform distribution of PPS in PI. The SEM images of the cross-section and the surface of the IFR-SPE in Fig. 3b and 3c indicate that the pores are filled with polymer electrolyte after polymerization and an integrated and compact solid electrolyte has been formed. Fig. 3d presents the typical mapping images about the corresponding elements (i.e., C, N, O, F, P, and S) on the electrolyte surface and the elements distribution is homogenerous in the whole area. The polymerization of BEPA and OPTTA has been further investigated using Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy. As shown in Fig. 4 a, the IR peaks in the range of 1610–1680 cm−1 are attributed to the C = C stretching vibration of the acrylate groups in BEPA and OPTTA. After polymerization, the characteristic C = C bond peaks disappear in the IFR-SPE, indicating the successful crosslinking reaction and formation of a new 3D framework. The X-ray diffraction patterns of the solid PEO electrolyte and IFR-SPE are compared in Fig. 4b. Sharp peaks at 21.0 and 23.5 of the PEO electrolyte indicates its semicrystalline structure and this generally results in the poor ionic conductivity. In contrast, the IFR-SPE has no evident crystallinity peak, which implies its amorphous structure and is helpful for enhancing the Li-ion conductivity. Another character of IFR-SPE is its high flexibility. Electronic digital photographs of 8 cm2 free-standing IFR-SPE film at different states are shown in Fig. S6. After abused via twisting, folding, and unfolding, the IFR-SPE film is able to regain its original shape.

Safety is vital to the application of LMB particularly for energy storage equipment in close proximity to the human body, such as electric vehicles, portable devices, and household storage devices. Thermal shrinkage is a vital factor to estimate the potential safety of the polymer electrolyte. Fig. 4c compares the shape changes of the PP separator, PI membrane, solid PEO/LiFSI electrolyte, and IFR-SPE with the temperature. After exposure to thermal condition (150 °C, 0.5 h), the PP separator was almost completely contracted, whereas the PI membrane evidently stayed in its original state. In addition, the PEO/LiFSI melted into viscous liquid when exposed to a high temperature (150 °C) for 30 min, which can cause the short circuit of battery and severe safety issues. By contrast, the IFR-SPE morphology was still stable at the same condition. The color change in PEO/LiFSI and IFR-SPE may arise from the reaction of LiFSI and moisture after thermal exposure in air-flow oven. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was applied to measure the thermal stability of IFR-SPE. Fig. 4d indicates that the IFR-SPE film was stable below 200 °C. Besides, the DSC of IFR-SPE and that without solvent or without salt have been measured as shown in Fig. S7. They did not show obvious Tg points, indicating that they have no crystallization. Significant endothermic peaks in them are caused by melting of LIFSI (melting point of 124–128 ℃) or thermal decomposition of FEC (130–150 ℃) [40]. All the samples showed high amorphous state, which could be mainly due to the presence of PI membrane, the cross-linking structure and existence of FEC solvent (or salt).

The flammability of PP absorbed by carbonate solvents EC + DMC (1:1, v/v), PEO/LiFSI, and IFR-SPE films has been examined using the direct flame test. As shown in Fig. 5 a and Video S2, the PP shrank and caught fire once ignited, and then burned violently. The PEO/LiFSI film still burned after the removal of exogenous lighter fire and burned out within 4 s (Fig. 5b and Video S3), indicating the poor safety performance. Fig. 5c and Video S4 demonstrate the flame test of the IFR-SPE film. The IFR-SPE slightly burned under the lighter fire but had no continuing combustion phenomenon after removing the lighter fire. At the same time, the IFR-SPE without PI supporting framework was ignited by flame and went out quickly within 0.4 s after removing the lighter fire (Fig. S8 a and Video S5). Besides, PI supporting framework is a N-containing fame-retardant material, which can not catch fire as shown in Figure S8 (b). The excellent fireproof property of IFR-SPE can be attributed to the flame-retardation of the phosphate group and the fireproof PI supporting framework in the polymer electrolyte. As interpreted in Fig. 5d, the phosphate group in the polymer framework can generate PO· free radicals once heated, which can capture H· and OH· released from polymer and further retard and stop polymer electrolyte combustion.

The ionic conductivity has great influence on the electrochemical performance of LMBs. The ionic conductivities of IFR-SPE with different LiFSI concentrations were measured using AC impedance techniques from 298 K to 333 K (Fig. 6 a). The IFR-SPE using 1.5 M LiFSI in PPS has higher Li-ion conductivity than those using lower salt concentration. This is accordance with some reported results [41,42]. In view of that higher slat concentration will increase cost and deteriorate the mechanical strength of polymer electrolytes, we adopt 1.5 M LiFSI in PPS. Its ionic conductivity reaches 0.28 mS cm−1 at room temperature and 0.48 mS cm−1 at 60 °C. The activation energy of lithium-ion conduction in IFR-SPE is 0.11 eV according to the Arrhenius equation.

The electrochemical Li plating/stripping cycle performance in IFR-SPE has been investigated by using Li/Li coin cell under galvanostatic condition. As shown in Fig. 6f, Li/IFR-SPE/Li cell presents an overvoltage about 70 mV at the initial cycling stage, and followed steady overvoltage as low as 0.042 V up to 1000 h at current density of 0.5 mA cm−2 and 0.5 mAh cm−2. The high interfacial resistance in the initial cycles could be attributed to some oxide and other impurities on the original Li foil. In general, the initial several cycles belong to the activation process, in which the Li electrode surface is gradually renewed and a SEI layer is formed, along with the decreased interfacial resistance and polarization. In addition, compared with the original Li surface, the repeated Li strapping and deposition increases the specific surface area more or less, which could also suppress the voltage polarization. Besides, we have also tested Li/LiFSI-FEC/Li and Li/LiFSI-EC-DMC/Li at current density of 0.5 mA cm−2 and 0.5 mAh cm−2. Li/LiFSI-EC-DMC/Li showed steady overvoltage about 55 mV to 120 h (Fig. S10a). For Li/LiFSI-FEC/Li (Fig. S10b), the cell showed increasing overvoltage to 130 mV at 110 h and finally it appears that micro-short-circuit occurred. We observed thick and dark interface layer. It may be caused by quick reaction between lithium and FEC. The great difference in cycling behavior for three types of electrolytes could arise from their different SEI composition and properties, which are, in turn, dominated by all the electrolyte components that could participate in side-reactions. The Li/IFR-SPE/Li cell after 100 cycles at 0.2 mA cm−2 with 0.2 mAh cm−2 was disassembled to check the Li morphology change. With IFR-SPE, the Li surface is still smooth after the cycling test (Fig. 6d). But many Li dendrites can be observed when liquid electrolyte is used (Fig. 6e). The larger area observation and comparison is illustrated in Fig. S11. These results indicate that use of IFR-SPE can not only improve the cycling reversibility, but also suppress Li dendrite growth.

As mentioned above, the SEI composition and chemical state influence the interfacial property and Li deposition behavior greatly. The surface of Li anode undergoing 100 cycles at 0.2 mA cm−2 with 0.2 mAh cm−2 in IFR-SPE has been analyzed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The distinct P 2p3/2 peaks at 130.4 and 133.2 eV, and P 2p1/2 peaks at 131.5 and 134.4 eV in Fig. 6g are assigned to the formation of Li3PO4. The Li3PO4 layer has a high Young’s modulus and good Li+ transport capacity [43]. On the other hand, the peak at 687.3 eV in Fig. 6h is assigned to LiFSI, but the strong peak at 685.1 eV indicates the existence of LiF, which is generated by decomposition of FEC and LiFSI as many papers revealed [44,45]. LiF is helpful for suppressing Li dendrite growth and promoting the cycle ability [45,46]. Fig. S12 (a) presents full XPS spectrum. In C 1 s XPS spectrum, the peaks at 284.8, 286.6, 288.3, and 289.6 eV in Fig. S12 (b) are assigned to C–C/C–H, C–O, C = O, and Li2CO3/C–F respectively, which originate from the decomposition of IFR-SPE. Fig. S12 (c) shows O 1 s spectrum, in which the peaks at 531.3, 532.6, and 533.4 eV could be attributed to ROLi/P–O, Li2CO3/LiOH, and ROCO2Li, respectively. The peaks at 54.3 and 55.4 eV in Li 1 s spectrum (Fig. S12 d) further confirm the existence of ROCO2Li/Li2CO3 and LiF. Overall, Li3PO4, LiF and organic lithium salts together, plus traditional Li2CO3 and LiOH, dominate the SEI composition and structure, which may improve the mechnical property and Li+ conductivity.

In order to evaluate the real applicability of IFR-SPE, The full Li/LiFePO4 cell has been fabricated via the in situ polymerization route and its electrochemical performances investigated. As shown in Fig. 7 a, the initial reversible capacity of LiFePO4 is 151.3 mA h g−1 at 0.2C and room temperature under the voltage range from 2.5 V to 4.0 V. Its capacity retention reaches 94.8% after 200 cycles with an average Coulombic efficiency of 99.4%, which is remarkably better than those of mostly reported solid LMBs (Table S1). For charge/discharge curves of Li/IFR-SPE/LFP cell in Fig. 7a, the initial some cycles with larger polarization belong to the activation process, in which the electrode surface is gradually renewed and a SEI layer is formed. After forming a stable SEI layer on electrode surface, there is a decreased interfacial resistance and polarization. In addition, the CV of Li/IFR-SPE/ LiFePO4 cell in Fig. S13 indicates that the redox reactions are reversible. Increasing current rate from 0.2C to 2C, then returning to 0.2C, the voltage ploarization is aggravated and the capacity decreases with enhanced rate. However, it is noteworthy that the reversible capacity can reach the original value when the rate returns to 0.2C (Fig. 7b). These results indicate the high electrochemical reversibility of the full cell.

In conclusion, we have prepared two novel synthetic monomers with P and successfully constructed an inherently flame-retardant solid polymer electrolyte for rechargeable Li metal batteries via the in situ polymerization technique. Compared with the flammable PP/liquid electrolyte and the solid PEO/Li salt-based solid electrolyte, the IFR-SPE shows excellent flame-retardant ability owing to the presence of phosphate group in the polymer framework. Moreover, it is compatible with Li metal electrode. The stable Li cycling and dendrite-free Li deposition with IFR-SPE could be attributed to the favorible LiF/Li3PO4-rich SEI layer. The excellent electrochemical performance of Li/FFR-PEO/LiFePO4 cell indicates that the proposed IFR-SPE is promising for the safety-enhanced and high-energy LMBs.
